name: market for weaned heifers, live weight | weaned heifers, live weight | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/19706/documentation

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.;This is the market for 'weaned heifers, live weight', in the geography of South Africa. This is a constrained market for consequential system model, for attributional system models, this is a regular market. In the case of consequential system model, details about the marginal consumer can be found in the comment of the conditional exchange (by-product).;This dataset represents the transport of 1 kg of live weight of weaned heifers from the weaner production system to the feedlot gate, ready for fattening. No losses are considered.;The product 'weaned heifers, live weight' is an animal farmed for meat. Beef cattle are typically farmed for 1-2 years. A heifer is an adult female bovine that has not yet given birth to a calf. The product represents the animal alive before transferring and processing in a slaughterhouse.

The activity starts at the farm gate.

The activity ends with the provision of weaned heifers, live weight, at the feedlot gate.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/014:Animal production/0141:Raising of cattle and buffaloes

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: South African values: Not applicable worldwide.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Data and assumptions are intended to reflect current equipment, processes and market conditions.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Transport distance estimate based on the breakdown of commercial cattle numbers on pasture and feedlot by province (du Toit et al, 2013). See comment field for numerous assumptions made. Reference(s): Du Toit, C.J.L., Meissner, H.H. & van Niekerk, W.A. (2013) Direct methane and nitrous oxide emissions of South African dairy and beef cattle, South African Journal of Animal Science (43) 320-339

exchanges.description: Estimated value based on the breakdown of commercial cattle numbers on pasture and feedlot by province (du Toit et al, 2013). It was assumed that first preference would be given to farms within the region, which amounted to 50% of cattle. It was further assumed that cattle are transported an average distance of 100km within the province. Not enough weaners are available for feedlot production in Gauteng (GP), North West (NW) and Free State (FS) Province. Therefore a weighted average distance was applied based on a breakdown of the surplus weaners available in the other provinces, including imports from Namibia (NAMMIC, 2015), and the distance from these regions to the feedlots in GP, NW and FS. The distances were estimated using Google Maps. Reference(s): Du Toit, C.J.L., Meissner, H.H. & van Niekerk, W.A. (2013) Direct methane and nitrous oxide emissions of South African dairy and beef cattle, South African Journal of Animal Science (43) 320-339; Strydom, P.E., Frylinck, L., van Heerden, S.M., Hope-Jones, M., Hugo, A., Webb, E.C., Moholisa, E., Liebenberg, B.E. & Sehoole, O.C. (2015) Sources of variation in quality of South African beef: case studies in relation to the red meat classification system, South African Journal of Animal Science (45) 289-301; NAMMIC (2015) Meat Board of Namibia Business Plan. Available at: http://www.nammic.com.na/index.php/library/send/15-business-plan/118-mbn-business-plan-2016.
